  • EntropicTree.find_subset
EntropicTree.find_subset â€” Function
find_subset(n::Int64,p,q,RV::AbstractString="X")
Given `i` and `j` compute `Îš âŠ† ğ’© \{i,j}`; i.e., all non exclusive subsets. `i,j` can also be empty (i.e. []), in which case the non-empty superset gets listed. An optional prefix can be added (default is `X`).  
#### Examples

Given i and j compute Îš âŠ† ğ’© \{i,j}; i.e., all non exclusive subsets. i,j can also be empty (i.e. []), in which case the non-empty superset gets listed. An optional prefix can be added (default is X).

Examples

julia>find_subset(4,1,3,"X")
["" "X1" "X1,X2" "X1,X2,X5" "X1,X5" "X2" "X2,X5" "X5"]

julia>find_subset(4,1,3,"")
["" "1" "1,2" "1,2,5" "1,5" "2" "2,5" "5"]

julia> find_subset(5,4,3,"ğŸ’")
["" "ğŸ’3" "ğŸ’3,ğŸ’4" "ğŸ’4"]

julia> find_subset(5,[],[],"ğŸ“")
["ğŸ“1" "ğŸ“1,ğŸ“2" "ğŸ“1,ğŸ“2,ğŸ“3" "ğŸ“1,ğŸ“3" "ğŸ“2" "ğŸ“2,ğŸ“3" "ğŸ“3"]
